. Thank you for your work on this. We have a plan for having a backend for the editor so you save Swaggers in a database with versioning. We are interested in JSBin model where we use path params (UUID) for identifier and another path param for versioning. Doing too much in client side has less value since you can't share all of those saved YAMLs and also if in middle of editing title you might see another YAML magically appear because it matched the title. 
. Yes, I'm actually designing the backend API for such system. It's going to be very similar to JSBin. The way it works is, for the first time you visit editor it renders / for you. Then when you make changes, we automatically push URL state to /:id/1 where id is unique for your Swagger description. Now, every time you make changes, we update the content of the Swagger description in the DB. If you click save button, we save current document as final for version 1 and push URL state to /:id/2. 
There is a bit more complexity to it, when you share your URL with someone else, if they make changes, because they don't have the "ownership" cookie in their browser we save that Swagger description as a new entity and push URL state to /:new-id/1 so people can't mess with each other Swagger specs.
Here is the Swagger for API I explained above:
``` yaml
swagger: 2.0
info:
  version: "1.0.0"
  title: Bins
  description: An api for bins
paths:
  /:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: Renders empty bin
    post:
      parameters:
        - name: body
          in: body
          schema:
            type: string
      responses:
        200:
          schema:
            $ref: Bin
          description: Makes a new bin
/:id:
    get:
      responses:
        200: 
          description: Gets latest version of the bin with id
    post:
      parameters:
        - name: body
          in: body
          schema:
            type: string
      responses:
        200:
          schema:
            $ref: Bin
          description: Makes a new version of the bin
    delete:
      responses:
        400:
          description: Delete is not supported
/:id/:version: 
    get:
      responses:
        200: 
          schema:
            $ref: Bin
          description: Gets a specific version of a bin
    delete:
      responses:
        400:
          description: Deletes is not supported
definitions:
  Bin:
    properties:
      uuid: 
        type: string
      versions:
        type: array
        items:
          $ref: Version
Version:
    properties:
      bin_id:
        type: string
      version:
        type: integer
      created_at:
        type: Date
      body:
        type: string
```

yaml
paths:
  /:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description:  List all pets
    post:
      parameters:
        $ref: "#parametes/Pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: Make a new pet
    put:
      parameters:
        $ref: "#parametes/Pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates the pet
parameters:
      - name: Pet
        in: body
        description: The pet JSON you want to post
        schema:
          $ref: '#/definitions/Pet'
        required: true
. I didn't know that. The $ref resolver really don't know about the schema. It just walks the tree with the given path. With that, you need to have the full path from root in your $ref value. It should work. 
. This has been fixed by 0aded6d and 8937fcc 
For the record, this is working example for using $ref in parameters:
``` yaml
swagger: 2
info:
  version: 0.0.0
  title: test
paths:
  /:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description:  List all pets
      parameters:
        -
          $ref: "#/parameters/Pet"
    post:
      parameters:
        -
          $ref: "#/parameters/Pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: Make a new pet
    put:
      parameters:
        -
          $ref: "#/parameters/Pet"
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates the pet
parameters:
  Pet:
    name: Pet
    in: body
    description: The pet JSON you want to post
    schema:
      $ref: Pet
    required: true
definitions:
  Pet:
    required:
      - id
      - name
    properties:
      id:
        type: integer
        format: int64
      name:
        type: string
      tag:
        type: string
``

. You are using shorthand$refsyntax which only works if your definition that you are referring to is indefinitionsarray (root level).
For parameters it's necessary to have full path in your$ref`.
See this example:
``` yaml
Example YAML for the bare minimum of required elements
swagger: 2.0
info:
  version: "1.0.0"
  title: petstore
parameters:
  productId: 
       name: productId
       in: path
       type: string
       required: true
paths:
  /users:
    get:
      parameters:
        -
          $ref: '#/parameters/productId'
      responses:
        "200":
          description:  Describe the 200 response in more detail
```
The resolver can be smart and lookup $refs that are in parameters array of a path in parameters:(root) but I'm not sure if that breaks the specs. Even our shorthand syntax for definitions is not standard according to JSON Schema but at least that is documented.
This is second time I see users are confused by this. @fehguy What you think about this? Should we make Resolver smarter and document it or remove shorthand syntax altogether? Currently it's a little confusing.

. @paraskakis Here is how $ref in JSON work:
If you intial JSON is like this:
json
{"my-property": { "$ref": "some-url"}}
and some-url resolves to "my-value", the object wrapping $ref will get replaced with "my-value" resulting to this:
json
{"my-property":  "my-value"}
Replacing range:
{"my-property": { "$ref": "some-url"}}
                ^                   ^
                |                   |__ to here
                |
                |______________________ from here

. The way anybin works is it saves an ownership cookie in your browser when you create a bin so you can write to the bin. If someone else without that cookie want to write to the bin, it will make a new bin based on original bin. Kind of like forking. There is also versioning. Every time users clicks "Save milestone" a new version of bin is saved and state of the bin is locked down. And because URLs are not sequential unless you give your bin's URL to someone they can't really find it (security! 🔓)

. From Swagger 2.0 specs standpoint yes, you can. You can have $refs to external files. For example, if your parameters_common.yaml is living in the same folder that your main YAML file is living then you can include that files like this:
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
parameters: 
  $ref: parameters_common.yaml
paths: 
 ...
Your parameters_common.yaml would be just the array of parameters 
yaml
- name: param_one
...
- name: param_two
...
This works fine in current editor if you host the editor yourself so parameters_common.yaml path can get resolved as an HTTP path. Currently there is no way to jump between files or create a new one.
If you are doing a big project with Swagger, I recommend hosting the editor yourself. When editor and the API you are building are on the same origin, XHR call don't have to be cross-origin which help editor to show more details about calls in "try-operation" and your API doesn't have to have cross origin headers.
. @newmanw Generators for 2.0 usually get one big specs file. If you have multiple files linked to each other (via $ref) you would need to resolve those links and make a large specs file then send it to generator.
. We thought about it and decided to not make an IDE from Swagger Editor. Swagger Editor can resolve remote and relative $refs. So if you want to have multiple files, host the editor and use a relative path in your $ref to refer to another file hosted in your server. (For example $ref: /my-model.yaml)
There is no end in making Swagger Editor similar to an IDE. 
Even with this decision in place, you are more than welcome to spend the time and implement this feature. After all this is an open source project.

. Hi @EricWittmann! I'm glad you're interested in helping. The plan is to have some UI controls like buttons for manipulating the swagger specs from preview panel. For example in parameters table, at the end of the table there should be button that says "add a new parameter" and clicking that button opens up a modal that has a form for making a new parameter (with all possible ways of making a parameter of course). Then after a parameter is created by that modal, we need to put that parameter back to specs. In case of JSON, it's simple because there is no comments and styling in JSON and regenerating all of JSON is fine. In case of YAML it's a bit trickier. We need to use ASTManager to insert the parameter exactly where it should be without re-generating the YAML from specs JavaScript object. We don't want to modify user's YAML structure or remove their comments. 
To get started, familiarize yourself with the project. There is a global mode variable that is accessible via $rootScope.mode in JS files or simply mode in templates. First step is to remove that alert and make the menu button override global mode. Then we want to add UI controls and limit their appearance to ng-if="mode === 'designer'" because those controls should be hidden in other modes.

. @tuukkamustonen You can define parameters globally using global parameters object. Then you can assign that parameter to each path. Every operation in that path will be using that parameter. 
See this example:
``` yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: 1.0.0
  title: Pets Store
parameters:
  x-something:
    name: X-Something
    in: header
    description: Global header X-Something
    type: string
paths:
  /pets:
    parameters:
      - $ref: '#/parameters/x-something'
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: Returns all the pets
``

. I believe if you try to put everything everything in one app it's going to be hard to maintain. It's nice to have auto-generated tests, mock server and try request in one app but let's have the editor scoped around editing the code and trying out endpoints.
Two points about creating a new app:
- Chrome Apps and Atom plugins can make requests with no limitations. See Postman(Chrome App) and HTTP Post(Atom package). There is no need of making a standalone app using Atom Shell just because of HTTP calls.
- Programmers love their own editor. They have plug-ins, custom key bindings and themes on their editors that they use everyday. If they could edit Swagger in their own editor (Atom in this case) it would be much more appealing than launching a different app for editing Swagger
. You can select Mode > Disable Live Render to disable per keypress updates. This will help you edit large Swagger spec documents.
. Yes, we can write our own diffing algorithm to update DOM partially. AngularJS is very good at doing this if we keep the source specs the same object, but what we override the source specs object each time user press a key because we transform hashes to arrays to keep the ordering right.
One solution is to not override the source object and perform a deep diff and update only parts that are changed. 
I'll look into it in feature

. Yes, that's how YAML works. If you don't put quotes around numbers they're going to be treated as numbers but if you don't put quotes around strings that can't parsed as numbers YAML will parse them as strings.
``` yaml
number: 12 # parsed as number
decimal: 0.00001 # parsed as number
notNumber: 123x # can't be a number
stringNum: "124" # because of the quotes it won't try parsing it
string: Hello world
because it's a multi-line string it won't try parsing this either
mlString: >
  12344 
```

@webron Does Swagger have a method for marking fragment files? Something like specifically formatted comments maybe?
. For Swagger Editor to support this we can have to have some specific comments. Here is my proposal for the spec of the comments I that indicates a YAML file is a partial swagger file:
1. First line MUST be a comment
2. Comment body is formatted as follows and containing  # partial-swagger: (space, partial-swagger, colon, space)
# partial-swagger: {{path}}
3. the path component can be a string or a JavaScript array. 
4. If path is string it is pointing to a root object in swagger document.
Example: 
yaml
   # partial-swagger: info
   title: My API
   description: An API
5. If path is an array it is pointing to an object deep inside the swagger document. It should be valid JavaScript(or JSON) array
   Example:
yaml
   # partial-swagger: ["info", "contact"]
   email: me@example.com
   url: example.com
   name: My Name
Obviously this is not part of Swagger spec and it's here only to help Swagger Editor work with partial YAMLs that build up a larger spec.

. From JSON Schema §5.23:
```
date-time  This SHOULD be a date in ISO 8601 format of YYYY-MM-
      DDThh:mm:ssZ in UTC time.  This is the recommended form of date/
      timestamp.
date  This SHOULD be a date in the format of YYYY-MM-DD.  It is
      recommended that you use the "date-time" format instead of "date"
      unless you need to transfer only the date part.
time  This SHOULD be a time in the format of hh:mm:ss.  It is
      recommended that you use the "date-time" format instead of "time"
      unless you need to transfer only the time part.
```
You probably want to use date-time that is in ISO 8601

. Yes, in YAML you should define an alias before using it. If you put definitions after paths the OperationType anchor is used before being defined. I recommend defining all of your anchors on top under a free-form swagger extension 
``` yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: "0.0.1"
  title: API
x-types:
  OperationType: &OperationType
    - registration
Describe your paths here
paths:
  /checker:
    get:
      parameters:
        - name: operations
          in: query
          type: array
          items:
            type: string
            enum: *OperationType
          default: [registration]
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/OperationType'
definitions:    
  OperationType:
    type: string
    enum: *OperationType
```

      description: User not found
    403:
      description: Permission denied
    default:
      description: unexpected error
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/ErrorModel'
  tags:
    - Users

/users/{id}/account:
    get:
      description: Returns a user account
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to fetch account for
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: fields
          in: query
          description: Comma delimited list of fields
          required: false
          type: string
        - name: embed
          in: query
          description: Comma delimited list of embedded objects
          required: false
          type: string
      responses:
        '200':
          description: account response depends on fields/embed
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Account'
        default:
          description: unexpected error
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/ErrorModel'
      tags:
        - Accounts
    put:
      description: |
        Updates account object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to update account for
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: account
          in: body
          description: The account JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/AccountUpdate'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates a account
      tags:
        - Accounts
/users/{id}/account/users:
    post:
      description: |

      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path

          required: true
          type: string
        - name: user
          in: body
          description: User object that needs to be updated
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateUser'

            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'

        - Accounts
/users/{id}/account/addresses:

      description: |

      parameters:
        - name: id

          type: string
        - name: address
          in: body
          description: The address JSON you want to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateAddress'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates an address
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Address
  /users/{id}/account/addresses/{addrid}:
    put:
      description: |
        Updates Address object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to update Address for
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: addrid
          in: path
          description: ID of Address to update
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: address
          in: body
          description: The address JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateAddress'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates an address
      tags:
        - Address
/users/{id}/quotes:
    post:
      description: |
        Creates quote object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to create a quote
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: quote
          in: body
          description: The quote JSON you want to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/NewQuote'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates a quote
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Quotes
/users/{id}/quotes/{qid}:
    put:
      description: |
        Updates quote object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to update quote for
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: qid
          in: path
          description: ID of quote you want to update
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: quote
          in: body
          description: The quote JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateQuote'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates a quote
      tags:
        - Quotes
get:
  description: Returns a quote for a user
  parameters:
    - name: id
      in: path
      description: ID of user to fetch
      required: true
      type: string
    - name: qid
      in: path
      description: ID of quote to fetch
      required: true
      type: string
    - name: fields
      in: query
      description: Comma delimited list of fields
      required: false
      type: string
    - name: embed
      in: query
      description: Comma delimited list of embedded objects
      required: false
      type: string
  responses:
    '200':
      description: quote response
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Quote'
    default:
      description: unexpected error
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/ErrorModel'
  tags:
    - Quotes

/users/{id}/quotes/{qid}/travelers:
    post:
      description: |
        Creates traveler object for a quote.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to create traveler
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: qid
          in: path
          description: ID of quote to create traveler
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: travelers
          in: body
          description: The array of travelers JSON you want to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/TravelersArray'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates a traveler, returns location to quote
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Quotes
/users/{id}/quotes/{qid}/travelers/{travuid}:
    put:
      description: |
        Updates traveler object for a quote.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to update traveler
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: qid
          in: path
          description: ID of quote to update traveler
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: travuid
          in: path
          description: ID of traveler to update
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: traveler
          in: body
          description: The traveler JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateTraveler'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates a traveler
      tags:
        - Quotes
delete:
  description: |
    Removes `traveler` object from quote.
  parameters:
    - name: id
      in: path
      description: ID of user to removes traveler
      required: true
      type: string
    - name: qid
      in: path
      description: ID of quote to remove traveler
      required: true
      type: string
    - name: travuid
      in: path
      description: ID of traveler to remove
      required: true
      type: string
  responses:
    200:
      description: traveler removed
  tags:
    - Quotes

/anon/quotes:
    post:
      description: |
        Creates quote object for anonymous user
      parameters:
        - name: quote
          in: body
          description: The quote JSON you want to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/NewAnonQuote'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates a quote, returns location of /anon/quote
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Quotes
/anon/quotes/{qid}:
    put:
      description: |
        Updates anonymous quote object.
      parameters:
        - name: qid
          in: path
          description: ID of quote to update
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: quote
          in: body
          description: The quote JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/UpdateAnonQuote'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Updates a quote
      tags:
        - Quotes
get:
  description: Returns a quote for anonymous user
  parameters:
    - name: qid
      in: path
      description: ID of quote to fetch
      required: true
      type: string
  responses:
    '200':
      description: quote response
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/AnonQuote'
    default:
      description: unexpected error
      schema:
        $ref: '#/definitions/ErrorModel'
  tags:
    - Quotes

/users/{id}/wishlist:
    post:
      description: |
        Creates wishlist object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to create a wishlist entry
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: wishlist
          in: body
          description: The wishlist JSON you want to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/NewWishlist'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates a Wishlist entry, returns location of User
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Wishlist
/users/{id}/wishlist/{pid}:
    delete:
      description: |
        Removes wishlist object for specified program.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to remove wishlist entry
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: pid
          in: path
          description: ID of program to remove from wishlist
          required: true
          type: string
      responses:
        200:
          description: Program removed fom wishlist, returns location of User
      tags:
        - Wishlist
/users/{id}/enrollments:
    post:
      description: |
        Finalizes a quote and creates an 'enrollment' object.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to create an enrollment
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: enrollmentheader
          in: body
          description: The enrollment header containing the quote id and payment info
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/EnrollmentHeader'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates an enrollment
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Enrollment'
  tags:
    - Enrollments

/users/{id}/enrollments/{eid}:
    get:
      description: Returns an enrollment for a user
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to fetch
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: eid
          in: path
          description: ID of enrollment to fetch
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: fields
          in: query
          description: Comma delimited list of fields
          required: false
          type: string
        - name: embed
          in: query
          description: Comma delimited list of embedded objects
          required: false
          type: string
      responses:
        '200':
          description: enrollment response
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Enrollment'
        default:
          description: unexpected error
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/ErrorModel'
      tags:
        - Enrollments
/users/{id}/enrollments/{eid}/payments:
    post:
      description: Creates a payment for an enrollment
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to create a payment
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: eid
          in: path
          description: ID of enrollment to create payment
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: payment
          in: body
          description: The payment JSON you want to put
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/NewPayment'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Creates a payment for an enrollment, returns location of enrollment
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
      tags:
        - Enrollments
/users/{id}/donations:
    post:
      description: |
        Posts a donation.
      parameters:
        - name: id
          in: path
          description: ID of user to post donation
          required: true
          type: string
        - name: donation
          in: body
          description: The donation JSON to post
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/NewDonation'
      responses:
        200:
          description: Donation posted
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Donation'
  tags:
    - Donations

definitions:
  User:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      GivenName:
        type: string
      Surname:
        type: string
      MiddleName:
        type: string
      LegalFirstName:
        type: string
      LegalMiddleName:
        type: string
      LegalLastName:
        type: string
      LegalidType:
        type: string
        description: LOV=ID_SOURCE, examples="US Driver's License", "US State Id"
      Email:
        type: string
      StudentId:
        type: string
      Ethnicity:
        type: string
      Dob:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      Gender:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Male",
              "Female"
            ]
      EmailOptin:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N",
              "Weekly"
            ]
      LikeNorthAmericanPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      LikeInternationalPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      LikeAfloatPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      Nickname:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      Prefix:
        type: string
        description: LOV=MR_MS, examples="Mr.", "Mrs."
      ReviewPrivacy:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      Suffix:
        type: string
        description: LOV=FINS_SUFFIX_MLOV, examples="Jr.", "Sr."
      Wishlist:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/WishlistGet'
          }
UpdateUser:
    required:
    - GivenName
    - Surname
    properties:
      GivenName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      Surname:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      MiddleName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      LegalFirstName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      LegalMiddleName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      LegalLastName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      LegalIdType:
        type: string
        description: LOV=ID_SOURCE, examples="US Driver's License", "US State Id"
      Email:
        type: string
        maxLength: 350
      Ethnicity:
        type: string
        description: LOV=RACE, examples="Black or African American", "White"
      Dob:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      Gender:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Male",
              "Female"
            ]
      EmailOptin:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N",
              "Weekly"
            ]
      LikeNorthAmericanPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      LikeInternationalPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      LikeAfloatPrograms:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      Nickname:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      Prefix:
        type: string
        description: LOV=MR_MS, examples="Mr.", "Mrs."
      ReviewPrivacy:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "Y",
              "N"
            ]
      Suffix:
        type: string
        description: LOV=FINS_SUFFIX_MLOV, examples="Jr.", "Sr."
NewUser:
    required:
    - Email
    properties:
      Email:
        type: string
        maxLength: 350
      IdmAuthId:
        type: string
Account:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      Name:
        type: string
      Salutation:
        type: string
      Sourcecode:
        type: string
      Addresses:
        type: array
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Address'
          }
      Users:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Pointer'
          }
      Enrollments:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Enrollment'
          }
      Vouchers:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Voucher'
          }
      Quotes:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/QuoteAccountGet'
          }
      Donations:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Donation'
          }
AccountUpdate:
    required:
    - Name
    - Salutation
    - Sourcecode
    properties:
      Name:
        type: string
        maxLength: 100
      Salutation:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      Sourcecode:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
Enrollment:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      OrderNumber:
        type: string
      GatewayId:
        type: string
      GatewayName:
        type: string
      Lodging:
        type: string
      Travelers:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/EnrollmentTraveler'
          }
      Preparations:
        type: array
        description: Only this array will be returned on /user/{id}/account GET
        description: optional=embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Preparation'
          }
      CustomFlightAirportCode:
        type: string
      TotalCost:
        type: number
      RemainingBalance:
        type: number
      PaymentHistory:
        type: array
        description: optional=field/embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/PaymentInfo'
          }
      Program:
        description: optional=embed
        $ref: '#/definitions/Program'
EnrollmentHeader:
    required:
    - QuoteId
    - PaymentInfo
    properties:
      QuoteId:
        type: string
      PaymentInfo:
        $ref: '#/definitions/NewPaymentWithVoucher'
PaymentInfo:
    properties:
      Authid:
        type: string
      Date:
        type: string
      PaymentAmt:
        type: integer
      VoucherAmt:
        type: integer
NewPayment:
    required:
    - AuthId
    - PaymentAmt
    properties:
      AuthId:
        type: string
      DonationAmt:
        type: integer
      PaymentAmt:
        type: integer
NewPaymentWithVoucher:
    required:
    - AuthId
    - PaymentAmt
    properties:
      AuthId:
        type: string
      DonationAmt:
        type: integer
      PaymentAmt:
        type: integer
      RedeemedVoucherId:
        type: string
Voucher:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      Amount:
        type: integer
Program:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      Name:
        type: string
      Number:
        type: string
      Description:
        type: string
      StartDate:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      EndDate:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
QuoteAccountGet:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      ProgramNumber:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
      Location:
        type: string
Quote:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      ProgramNumber:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
      GateWayId:
        type: string
      Location:
        type: string
      LodgingId:
        type: string
      Travelers:
        type: array
        description: optional=embed
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Traveler'
          }
      CustomFlightAirportCode:
        type: string
      SuggestedDonation:
        type: number
        description: optional=field
NewQuote:
    required:
    - ProgramDateId
    - MailCode
    - LodgingId
    properties:
      CustomFlightAirportCode:
        type: string
      GatewayId:
        type: string
      LodgingId:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
UpdateQuote:
    required:
    - ProgramDateId
    - LodgingId
    properties:
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      GatewayId:
        type: string
      LodgingId:
        type: string
      CustomFlightAirportCode:
        type: string
TravelersArray:
    properties:
      Travelers:
        type: array
        items: {
          $ref: '#/definitions/Traveler'
          }
Traveler:
    required:
    - UserId
    properties:
      UserId:
        type: string
      MealOption:
        type: string
        description: LOV=SIF_MEAL_CODE, examples="Low Fat", "Low Salt"
      SeatingOption:
        type: string
      RoommatePref:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
UpdateTraveler:
    properties:
      MealOption:
        type: string
        description: LOV=SIF_MEAL_CODE, examples="Low Fat", "Low Salt"
      SeatingOption:
        type: string
      RoommatePref:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
EnrollmentTraveler:
    required:
    - UserId
    properties:
      UserId:
        type: string
      MealOption:
        type: string
        description: LOV=SIF_MEAL_CODE, examples="Low Fat", "Low Salt"
      SeatingOption:
        type: string
      RoommatePref:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
NewAnonQuote:
    required:
    - WebsiteUserIdentifier
    - ProgramDateId
    - MailCode
    properties:
      WebsiteUserIdentifier:
        type: string
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      GatewayId:
        type: string
UpdateAnonQuote:
    properties:
      UserId:
        type: string
        description: pass user id to convert quote from anonymous to account
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      GatewayId:
        type: string
      LodgingId:
        type: string
      CustomFlightAirportCode:
        type: string
AnonQuote:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      ProgramDateId:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
      GatewayId:
        type: string
      LodgingId:
        type: string
Preparation:
    properties:
      UserId:
        type: string
      Name:
        type: string
      DueDate:
        type: string
      Status:
        type: string
      Url:
        type: string
Donation:
    required:
    - Amount
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      Amount:
        type: number
      Date:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      Authid:
        type: string
      Tribute:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Tribute'
      Purpose:
        type: string
      MailCode:
        type: string
NewDonation:
    required:
    - Amount
    properties:
      Amount:
        type: integer
      Authid:
        type: string
      Tribute:
        $ref: '#/definitions/Tribute'
      Purpose:
        type: string
        description: LOV=HH_DON_CLASS, examples="Where needed most", "Scholarships"
      Mailcode:
        type: string
        maxLength: 30
      ReceipteMail:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "",
              "Y"
            ]
      ReceiptMail:
        type: string
        enum: [
              "",
              "Y"
            ]
Tribute:
    properties:
      Type:
        type: string
        enum: [
          "In honor of",
          "In memory of"
          ]
      TributeName:
        type: string
        description: who the tribute is in honor or memory of
      FirstName:
        type: string
        description: first name of who will receive notification of donation
      LastName:
        type: string
        description: last name of who will receive notification of donation
      Street:
        type: string
        description: address of who will receive notification of donation
      City:
        type: string
        description: address of who will receive notification of donation
      State:
        type: string
        description: address of who will receive notification of donation
      Zip:
        type: string
        description: address of who will receive notification of donation
Address:
    properties:
      Id:
        type: string
      AddressName:
        type: string
      City:
        type: string
      State:
        type: string
      Country:
        type: string
      Phone:
        type: string
      Ext:
        type: string
      Zip:
        type: string
      Validfrom:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      Validto:
        type: string
        description: mm/dd/yyyy
        format: date
      EveryYear:
        type: string
        format: boolean
UpdateAddress:
    required:
    - AddressName
    - City
    - Country
    properties:
      AddressName:
        type: string
        maxLength: 200
      City:
        type: string
        maxLength: 50
      State:
        type: string
        description: LOV=STATE_ABBREV, examples="MA", "NY"
      Country:
        type: string
        description: LOV=COUNTRY, examples="USA", "Canada"
      Phone:
        type: string
        maxLength: 40
        description: phone and ext combined can be 40 chars max
      Ext:
        type: string
        description: phone and ext combined can be 40 chars max
      Zip:
        type: string

. in the editor, it's a little odd.  Simply put, the relative URL is supposed to be relative to the location of the swagger definition.
If the swagger URL was loaded from http://foo.bar.com/swagger.json, the relative location should be http://foo.bar.com/schema/response-status.schema.  If the URL was loaded from http://foo.bar.com/ (note, trailing slash), it'd be relative to that location.
But since the editor doesn't have a location to load from (you could import it), the relative location doesn't make much sense.  If we had to solve this, I would say it's relative to the scheme + host + basePath location, but even that you could argue is wrong.

. Try changing the response type to Animal, which is a common pattern:
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: 0.0.0
  title: Simple API
paths:
  /:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
          schema: 
            $ref: "#/definitions/Animal"
definitions:
  Animal:
    type: object
    discriminator: petType
    properties:
      commonName:
        type: string
  Cat:
    allOf:
      - $ref: '#/definitions/Animal'
      - type: object
        properties:
          isFurry:
            type: boolean
            default: false
This will define the basic response as an Animal and concrete implementations by the discriminator field.
. It is a tiny bit different.  Think of Animal as the generic response for the operation--it returns some kind of animal but you don't know what.
When the discriminator value is set to Cat in the response, the client knows that the response type is actually a Cat rather than generic Animal.
Since we don't actually know what type could be in the response (it may refer to Alien) of which there is no definition in the schema, we look at the allOf references.  Because Cat is referencing Animal in an allOf construct, we know that it's a possible response type, and therefore it is "in use".
Does that make sense?

. Hi, you cannot use $ref with any sibling attributes.  This isn't an issue with swagger, it's a design constraint of JSON pointers.  It shouldn't be allowed in Apiary's tool, either, you should open a bug there.  Furthermore your use of $ref with path parameters is forbidden by the spec.  You can only use primitives or arrays of primitives.
If you want to reuse your definition of, say, IntID, consider something like this:
``` yaml
...
get:
    parameters:
      - $ref: '#/parameters/IntID'
...
parameters:
  IntID:
    in: path
    name: id
    type: number
    format: double
    minimum: 1
``

. Yes, you can only use strings for the required array, and they should reference existing, available property names.. That's not quite what I'm saying.  You would declare the required fields inside your object.  So for example:
yaml
User:
  required:
  - id  # id is required
  - address # the address object is required, but we don't specify _here_ what is required in the object itself
  properties:
    id:
      type: string
    address:
      type: object
      required:
      - street # street property is required
      properties:
        street:
          type: string
So think of the required attribute as having "no object depth".  It only applies to properties in the current hierarchical scope.  If you want to look into an object property, you would define it there, like I did in the address object. We can't change the syntax for the required field because it's straight from JSON schema.  But possibly improve the display.  Can you please explain more?

. @mohsen1 - as far as I can tell, format is defined as type: string throughout the schema with no additional restrictions, so it doesn't seem to be a schema bug in this case.
. @whitlockjc -

However, the format property is an open string-valued property, and can have any value to support documentation needs. Formats such as "email", "uuid", etc., can be used even though they are not defined by this specification. Types that are not accompanied by a format property follow their definition from the JSON Schema (except for file type which is defined above).

So, for example, whether true or not, JeremyIsAwesome is a valid format.
@mohsen1 - the type has no affect on the validity of a format. How or whether the value is validated though is a different matter.
. I'm afraid that's inaccurate as well. From http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html#anchor106 - 

Implementations MAY support the "format" keyword. Should they choose to do so:
they SHOULD implement validation for attributes defined below;
they SHOULD offer an option to disable validation for this keyword.
Implementations MAY add custom format attributes. Save for agreement between parties, schema authors SHALL NOT expect a peer implementation to support this keyword and/or custom format attributes.

That suggests that if the formats are unknown, they can (and should) be ignored.
. It's an implementation and they may have chosen to not turn off validation of unknown formats. The JSON Schema specification explicitly says they are allowed, and in fact, JSON Schema's JSON Schema is non-restrictive - https://github.com/json-schema/json-schema/blob/master/draft-04/schema#L140.
And just because they all fail, doesn't mean they don't all have a bug in them. I didn't write that specification :)

. Whenever you describe a model, make sure to add type: object.
For example:
yaml
  Value:
    type: object
    properties:
      amount:
        type: number
        format: float
      currency: 
        type: string
      country:
        type: string
      region:
        type: string
. Two more points (not that any should give you the error, but changing it would solve your problem):
- You can't have anything alongside a $ref, so remove the type: object in those occurrences.
- You don't need format: string with type: string. Remove the format and the generation would work.

. You have to put those under the same entry:
yaml
  /profile:
    get:
      summary: Profile
      description: Returns the current user's profile.
      parameters:
        - name: provider
          in: query
          description: Storage provider
          required: false
          type: string
      tags:
        - Profile
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Profile
          schema:
            type: object
            $ref: '#/definitions/Profile'
        '400':
          description: Unexpected error
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Error'
    put:
      summary: Profile
      description: Updates the current user's profile.
      tags:
        - Profile
      parameters:
        - name: provider
          in: query
          description: Storage provider
          required: false
          type: string
        - name: name
          in: query
          description: name
          required: false
          type: string
        - name: bio
          in: query
          description: bio
          required: false
          type: string
        - name: photo
          in: formData
          description: photo upload
          required: false
          type: file
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Profile
          schema:
            type: object
            $ref: '#/definitions/Profile'
        '400':
          description: Unexpected error
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Error'

. To clarify, the type field is not mandatory. However, the lack of type means that the type is a wildcard. Specifying properties does not set the type to be an object implicitly. It means that if the value that's passed is an object, it will be validated against the properties, however, the value will also be valid if it's a string, number, boolean, array... you get the idea. As a best practice, you should always specify the type.
When it comes to rendering type-less definitions, that ends up being challenging for that exact reason.

. Perhaps I didn't explain properly, apologies. Anything that comes after the ? is query parameters by definition. Even if you define them as part of the path with fixed values, those are still query parameters. That's just how query parameters are defined. The spec simply does not support that. They cannot be considered part of the path, and cannot be treated as path parameters. This has nothing to do with the editor, this has to do with the spec. And the editor should not support things that are not supported by the spec itself, so yes, it would deliberately reject those.
. Future spec versions may or may not support it, I have no way of knowing.
Whether 'most' swagger tools support it or not, is not really relevant. It's not even relevant how easy it is to support it, as we simply will not provide support for it if it's not supported by the spec. I'm afraid that with the current spec, this is a definite won't fix.

Following @centromere's directions, I've modified the spec to contain:
yaml
  /pets/findByTags:
    post:
      tags:
        - pet
      summary: Finds Pets by tags
      description: Muliple tags can be provided with comma seperated strings. Use tag1, tag2, tag3 for testing.
      operationId: findPetsByTags
      produces:
        - application/json
        - application/xml
      consumes:
        - application/x-www-form-urlencoded
      parameters:
        - in: formData
          name: tags
          description: Tags to filter by
          required: false
          type: array
          items:
            type: string
          collectionFormat: multi
      responses:
        "200":
          description: successful operation
          schema:
            type: array
            items:
              $ref: "#/definitions/Pet"
        "400":
          description: Invalid tag value
      security:
        - petstore_auth:
          - write_pets
          - read_pets
When running Send Request, the payload clearly shows that two formData parameters are being sent, but with the name tags[] instead of tags.

. @saharj keep in mind that the test you referenced tests query parameters and not formData, even though the behavior is similar.
Today, the name of the parameter in the url or payload will always be the name of the parameter in the spec. The collectionFormat never affects the name. That means, that even if the collectionFormatis multi, the name of the parameter will stay as defined (that is, no square brackets are added). The only way to add the square brackets is to actually name the parameter with the square brackets (that is, tags[] instead of tags).
The collectionFormat affects how multiple values are sent. csv will separate them by , and so will all other formats, except for multi. multi is the only one that instead of adding a separator character, will repeat the parameter name, each time with a different value. This, again, will not change the name of the parameter as it is constructed in the request.

Putting the spec aside, you're trying to describe an enum in your code, which is used in the API.
If I understand, you want a numeric-values enum, but would also like to provide, in the code, a description to those numbers.
The spec, today, does not support providing descriptions to enums. It's an existing limitation, one which does not change in the next version. The limitation is derived from the capabilities of JSON Schema.
The best way to describe enum values in the spec is indeed in the documentation. This, however, will not reflect back to the code.
The example you gave:
yaml
MyEnum:
    type: integer
    enum:
      - value: 3
        description: Value 1
      - value: 10
        description: Value 2
is technically a valid definition (enum values can be objects) but in terms of validation, nothing would validate against it - what you are effectively saying here is that MyEnum is both an integer and an object (the objects limited by the enum) and nothing will be both.
Given those limitations, you need to decide what you want to achieve, and hopefully I can guide you through it.. Trust me, I'm well aware of the issue, and it's a common request. 
When it comes to the spec itself, we've considered extending support for it in the next version, but eventually decided against it. The main issue is that this is just not how JSON Schema works and we have little control over JSON Schema. Going outside the bounds of JSON Schema (not by adding but by changing existing features) will cause any tool that does JSON Schema to break - less tooling support in general. We're not giving up on it, just don't have a solution yet.
As for extending our tools - we're committed to create tools that are compliant with the spec. That means that making changes that break compliance is not on our roadmap. However, we might consider adding non-breaking extensions at some point (we do something small like that in swagger-ui) but I cannot give you a timeline for it (nor a guarantee).. . I'm not sure which validator you're using, but some let you pre-register remote refs so they can be loaded without making HTTP calls.  E.g. with z-schema:
javascript
validator.setRemoteReference(requiredUrl, JSON.parse(schema));
That's a workaround for the XHR issues, but it also has the advantage of making offline validation possible. I assume that interests you since you mentioned offline work in https://github.com/wordnik/swagger-editor/issues/193.

. I think it's actually more than best practice. A developer should be able to rebuild the image with their development branch. That is currently not possible since all of the steps are hidden away in the base image.
. @marcellodesales No worries! 
The docker build cache actually caches every step, so you don't gain anything by splitting it into multiple Dockerfiles. Try it out! The only time it will not use the cache is after an ADD if the hash of the files changes. So I always do ADD . as one of the last steps.  For builds like this that have dependencies in a file, you can ADD package.json first, so that it only re-builds those steps when dependencies change (not when any file changes).
I put out a CR that was merged (#188). Most of the steps are from docker history from the original image, so it should be pretty close to what you had in the base images.
. You are right that it wouldn't know about transitive dependencies.
It will bust the cache for every step after an un-cached ADD, so if the dependencies in package.json change, the following steps are run. But, if package.json doesn't change, it continues to use the cache for all steps until it finds an ADD that has changed.
To pickup transitive dependencies that aren't reflected in a package.json you'd have to run --no-cache.
Python deals with this problem by storing both: immediate dependencies in setup.py, and a full list of all dependencies (including transitive), in a requirements.txt.  I'm not sure if npm has any similar mechanism.
. Thanks!

. The swagger spec says the host can only be a hostname or ip address. It does not support path.
If you want to use a subdirectory then look into the basePath property.
https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-spec/blob/master/versions/2.0.md
"The host (name or ip) serving the API. This MUST be the host only and does not include the scheme nor sub-paths. It MAY include a port. If the host is not included, the host serving the documentation is to be used (including the port). The host does not support path templating."

. I am fairly sure it used to support XML. 
Adding try support to swagger editor back in Dec 2014 even has XML support ticked off.
So what I was expecting to happen is what the spec says - swagger editor would take the JSON schema representation and generate an object of the required content type (as set by 'Content-Type'), in this case application/xml.
There are XML specific attributes that can be set in the JSON Schema, but they are not required.

. Since you say your issue is about generating client code, you likely want to raise it here: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-codegen. Required attributes have to be local to that object itself - they cannot be ones inherited from other objects.
In your example if you want to make name and email required then they should be marked required on the object that declares them ("user").
Slightly odd I know, but that just seems to be how swagger works.. The swagger spec says description fields are GH flavour markdown not HTML. So it is quite correct for HTML to be escaped.
See https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/ for tips on using markdown.. Every day a school day, thanks for the correction @webron 👍 .

. Here is an update on the workaround that we have found...
We have worked around this problem by "normalizing" all the yaml files into one big file as part of the build process. This allows the tools to work on the one big file, but we can still develop and manage the files as separate files.
I believe swagger-codegen has templates for normalizing all the separate files, but we have been using the tool from Reprezen. A great eclipse based tool and the product support is awesome!. @terencechow (sorry for the really slow response!)
My solution using Reprezen would work with swagger editor only by normalizing all the swagger files into one first, then loading it into swagger-codegen. Not really a good solution for swagger editor.
But we are using Reprezen instead of swagger editor to design our spec. I hope this answers your question. . +1

In the apiman project ( http://apiman.io/ ) we're likely going to be integrating swagger in the next few months.  The existing swagger tools are great, and we'll use them as-is.  I noticed that the Swagger Editor was a text editor (yaml editor with live preview) and thought it would be great to have something more Designer-like.  
Because it's not critical path to our project, and because it seems like a reasonably meaty contribution, I thought this might make a great senior project for one of the schools we work with for such things.  Then I saw the "Designer" menu item and thought "uh oh, I'd better run it past these guys first to see what they think".
So that was going to be my suggestion - if you're interested, we could come up with a set of requirements for a pie-in-the-sky visual/wysiwyg editor and get it implemented as a formal project.

. @mohsen1  Maybe yes. I will check it today.
. javascript
$.getJSON('/config/defaults.json')
This make a request base on the url root. if we deploy the dist folder to sub path like http://domain.com/editor/index.html. Then it get the defaults.json by the url http://domain.com/config/defaults.json so throw a 404. 
the window.location.pathname would be end with '/' or 'html' or a dirname like 'editor'. When it end with '/', it dosen't need to add a root path,just change the '/config/defaults.json' to './config/defaults.json' will be ok. When it end with 'html' or a dirname like 'editor' , the root path is the parent directory, so rootPath = pathname + '/../' . This logic fixes the defaults.json and the examples yaml 404 error, when deploy it in a sub folder or reverse proxy by nginx.

I believe if you try to put everything everything in one app it's going to
be hard to maintain. It's nice to have auto-generated tests, mock server
and try request in one app but let's have the editor scoped around editing
the code and trying out endpoints.
Two points about creating a new app:
- Chrome Apps and Atom plugins can make requests with no limitations.
  See Postman(Chrome App)
  https://github.com/a85/POSTMan-Chrome-Extension and HTTP Post(Atom
  package) https://atom.io/packages/http-post. There is no need of
  making a standalone app using Atom Shell just because of HTTP calls.
- Programmers love their own editor. They have plug-ins, custom key
  bindings and themes on their editors that they use everyday. If they could
  edit Swagger in their own editor (Atom in this case) it would be much more
  appealing than launching a different app for editing Swagger
—

nickretallack:
Oddly, this only happens inside of the "definitions" block.  allOf works fine inside a schema block.
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: "0.0.0"
  title: Example
paths:
  /test:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
          schema:
            allOf:
              - $ref: '#/definitions/One' 
              - format: something
definitions:
  One:
    type: object
. Another similar document that doesn't cause the error:
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: "0.0.0"
  title: Example
paths:
  /test:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
definitions:
  Two:
    allOf:
      - $ref: '#/definitions/One' 
      - $ref: '#/definitions/Three'
  One:
    type: object 
  Three:
    format: something
This is a suitable workaround for now, since it is pretty much equivalent to the spec I want to write.  It also demonstrates the problem:
allOf, when used inside a definition, expects all of its children to be $refs.
. This schema also crashes the validator:
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: "0.0.0"
  title: Example
paths:
  /test:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
definitions:
  One:
    type: object
  Two:
    allOf: 
      - $ref: '#/definitions/One'
This time it's for a slightly different reason.  This time the error is:
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot convert undefined or null to object
It seems to be expecting One to have properties.  Adding properties there fixes it:
yaml
swagger: '2.0'
info:
  version: "0.0.0"
  title: Example
paths:
  /test:
    get:
      responses:
        200:
          description: OK
definitions:
  One:
    type: object
    properties:
      foo:
        type: string
  Two:
    allOf: 
      - $ref: '#/definitions/One'

Example YAML to get you started quickly.

This is your document metadata

Describe your paths here

        Gets Person objects.
        Optional query param of size determines
        size of returned array
      # This is array of GET operation parameters:

        # An example parameter that is in query and is required
        -
          name: size
          in: query
          description: Size of array
          required: true
          type: number
          format: double
      # Expected responses for this operation:
      responses:
        # Response code
        200:
          description: Successful response
          # A schema describing your response object.
          # Use JSON Schema format

            type: array
            items:
              title: Person
              type: object
              properties:
                name:
                  type: string
                single:
                  type: boolean
```
From my understanding of the spec, there is no way how a 'parameters' key could ever be an array instead of the defined object.
(My personal opinion is that the way, the editor implements it, is more intuitive because you don't have to come up with a 'random' key for the parameter but more imoprtant is that its compliant)
. So just got through it again, I am totally wrong. I must have assumed that for operations, the parameters key is the same as for the general document but indeed, the spec says for operations this is different like you implemented it in the editor.
(The Parameters object is meant to be a template for parameters)

```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-Powered-By: Express

Content-Length: 1282
ETag: W/"ekK93sn2UZ8QESF9+3OIOQ=="

Connection: keep-alive
{"the expected and properly formed JSON object here"}

. Since I was running swagger-editor and my own application's node server both on localhost, I didn't think I needed to allow CORS.  I turned on the CORS middleware on my application's express server, allowed localhost:9000 and the request from swagger-editor now works correctly.  Thanks.

pfebolo:
My goal is to have descriptions in multiple lines, paragraphs with simil tables, etc. In YAML this is possible with the | (verical bar) tag. This tag is not properly parsed by the editor simply does not recognize the line break.  To workarround the problem, I use the HTML tag . 
Example
```
paths:
  /ordenesdeproducto:
    post:
      tags:
        - Default
      summary: Crea orden de producto.
      description: |
        Crea una orden de venta de productos.
        Los datos obligatorios son los siguientes.
        Linea 3.
        Linea 4.
```
| Result in |
| --- |
Description
Crea una orden de venta de productos. Los datos obligatorios son los siguientes. Linea 3. Linea 4.
| my wish |
| --- |
Description
Crea una orden de venta de productos.
Los datos obligatorios son los siguientes.
Linea 3.
Linea 4.
regards
. Always learn something new, finally the trick was to finish the lines with 2 or more spaces.
Thank you very much.
.

. Ok, I figured out what the problem is. When you are using a $ref, it should'n have a sibling, otherwise you'll get a warning (it's weird that I didn't!). That's because when there is a $ref, everything (including $ref itself) will be replaced with the result of what that $ref is pointing to. So if you put siblings next to a $ref, they will not appear because resolver replaces it.

. We're using Sway which uses JSON Refs for resolving JSON Pointers. JSON Refs is using Path Loader for loading URLs.
~~Path loader has PrepareRequestCallback option that allows us to override the request location. With that I thought we can replace the request location based on an option set by Swagger Editor user.~~
JSON Refs provide relativeBase option which is a shortcut for what I described above
If we override origin and base path for each request in PrepareRequestCallback during resolution of $refs we will have a working remote resolver. Even if a remote JSON Pointer result have another $ref that points to another relative remote JSON Pointer.
Here is an example:
index.swagger.yaml
yaml
root:
  $ref: './a.yaml'
a.yaml
yaml
a: 
  $ref: '../b.yaml'
b.yaml
yaml
foo: bar
Lets say index.swagger.yaml is located at example.com/swaggers/my-swagger/index.swagger.yaml but we're trying to edit it in Swagger Editor, so we copy the contents to Swagger Editor and tell Swagger Editor to resolve all $refs from example.com/swaggers/my-swagger base. 
- a.yaml will get requested to editor.swagger.io/a.yaml but we override the base with example.com/swaggers/my-swagger and it resolves fine
- b.yaml will get requested to editor.swagger.io/../a.yaml but we override the base with example.com/swaggers/my-swagger and resolve it to example.com/swaggers/my-swagge/../b.yaml and it will resolve fine as well.
My plan is to add an option to preferences for the base URL of resolving $refs and use that in $ref resolution.

If we can get back the original behavior (resolving up to n levels) or at least have that as an option in JSON Refs, we can't do much.

. I looked into it and here is what's happening:
Swagger Editor uses the key in definitions object for JSON Schemas with no title. If you provide a title for your JSON Schema that title will be used. 
- Definition A refers to a definition that has no title so the key in the definitions object ("string-ref") is used
- Definition B is result of merger of two JSON Schemas. One the referred one and the other one has the title B. When we merge allOf, the later wins so "B" becomes the title
- Definitions C is not having a title property so we're using the key in definitions 
All of this is expected behavior and I don't think it's a bug.

. @cmhakkim Your YAML is not valid. Changing the `Awol` inside the `definition` will fix your problem. See below:
Awol:
    type: object
    allOf:
      - $ref: "#/definitions/Foo"
      - $ref: "#/definitions/Bar"
    properties:
      xxx:
        type: string
        format: date
      yyy:
        type: integer
      zzz:
        type: boolean
    required:
      - xxx
``. The problem is that you have defined atypeforin: bodyinstead ofschema`. You can either change the parameters to:
parameters:
        - name: task 
          in: body
          description: task object
          required: true
          schema: 
           type: string
or change the in: body to in: formData if that works for you.

Nevertheless thanks, I will keep it in mind for when I stumble upon such problem again..
mudithae:
ProxyPreserveHost On did the trick for me.

.
mpbunch:
-- Mental Note -- 
ProxyPass               / http://127.0.0.1:81/
The trailing slash is required for assets to load correctly else:
Proxy Error
The proxy server received an invalid response from an upstream server.
The proxy server could not handle the request GET /css/typography.css.
Reason: DNS lookup failure for: 127.0.0.1:81css
.
Robinyo:
I believe the issue was caused by a recent migration to OS X Yosemite.
What fixed the problem for me was to uninstall then reinstall node via brew:
npm cache clean
brew uninstall --force node
rm -r /usr/local/lib/node_modules
brew install node
'which node' returns /usr/local/bin/node
And, to set NODE_PATH in my .bash_profile:
export NODE_PATH=/usr/local/lib/node_modules
Note: npm works without sudo
.

hamx0r:
Ah, it wasn't clear what flavor of regex was to be used, though in hindsight, JS syntax seems the most obvious choice.
To future viewers:  Here's a snippet to convert from Python regex to JS.  It will be included in the Pyramid Cornice Swagger module at some point so that those using Colander with the Email validator or even their own pure-string regex (Python 2.4+) values will yield valid Swagger specs:
python
 m = re.match('\(\?([iLmsux]*)\)(.*)', pattern)
if m is None:
    js_re = '/' + pattern + '/'
else:
    flags = m.group(1)
    js_re = '/' + m.group(2) + '/'
    if 'i' in flags:
        js_re += 'i'
    if 'm' in flags:
        js_re += 'm'
    if 'g' in flags:
        js_re += 's'
parameter['pattern'] = js_re
.

andylowry:
I'm not a fan of specifying where a fragment belongs in the root spec, within the fragment itself. If I'm reusing something in more than one root spec, I may want it to be accessed by different paths in those specs. Or if want to reference it more than once in a single spec, I'm forced to place it in some placeholder in the root spec and then use local refs where I want the fragment to appear.
The existing support for JSON refs seems adequate with the sole exception of not supporting the editing of fragments, and it avoids the issue of nailing down in the fragment where it belongs in any root spec that references it.
Since the only limitation occurs during editing, it seems that comments are not required at all - merely an editor GUI option to state that the fragment is not a Swagger spec (and so should be treated as a plain JSON or YAML object by the editor). The editor could even be smart enough to offer, when it loads an object without swagger root property, to switch to non-swagger editing mode, or silently default to that and dynamically switch if a swagger root property is added. Or whatever...
. @mohsen1  Makes sense re the automatic switch. Still it might be helpful to  have it offered when a syntactically valid object is loaded without  a 'swagger' root element. It would avoid the hassle and ugliness of  loading a non-swagger document and then putting up with the error  messages until the editing mode is manually switched.
. @chris922 You might want to take a look at RepreZen API Studio. It includes a generator ("GenTemplate"in API Studio lingo) called "Swagger Normalizer" that can turn a multi-file swagger specification into an equivalent single file, suitable for software that does not deal well with multifile specifications.
There's a youtube video that talks more broadly about API Studio's support for multi-file swagger specifications.
[Disclaimer: I work for RepreZen]. A few comments on motivation for this feature:
Swagger specifically recommends model reuse through JSON references. However, it is currently difficult to do this in the editor, except in cases where the referenced models are hosted in the same domain as the editor itself.
For organizations aiming to promote internal reuse, same-domain is not much of a challenge. For developers hoping to reference models shared in external repositories (notably github), use of a CORS proxy may be the only viable approach.

. @webron The definition of a Schema Object explicitly lists type among the properties that are "taken directly from the JSON Schema definition and follow the same specifications". This would include arrays of strings, see JSON Schema Validation, section 5.5.2.
Both Swagger UI and Swagger Editor gracefully handle array values for type.
Only for Parameter Objects other than body parameters the spec explicitly restricts type to a single string value. 
. @fehguy Seeing the number of people asking for it: is there already a consensus forming on which way the spec wants to go?
. Well, it still is an issue: just pulled the latest Swagger UI and what I get is this:

When will the HTML be interpreted and rendered by the new editor?. @webron Actually the Swagger 2.0 spec literally says in Schema Object that type  is 

taken directly from the JSON Schema [Draft 04] definition and follow[s] the same specifications

JSON Schema (including Draft 04) explicitly allows arrays for type. 
Also it´s the only way to express nullable properties in Swagger 2.0 due to the lack of anyOf. Hiding nullability in the Swagger descriptions would most likely cause problems when generated client code encounters null values in real life.
We are currently faced with the dilemma that we really want to move from Swagger 2.0 and the corresponding 2.x tools to OpenAPI 3.0.1 and the corresponing 3.x tools, but we have hundreds of Swagger descriptions that work fine with the 2.x tools and appear to be incorrect when viewed with Swagger Editor 3.x.
How to proceed?. Ok, found it - very nicely structured source code! :+1:

Remove validateTypeKeyShouldBeString from src/plugins/validate-semantic/validators/schema.js, 
Then npm run build

And all is well. JSON Schema validation ensures that type only has one of the allowed string values in OAS3 files, so this only affects Swagger/OAS 2.0 files.
Would be nice if this could become part of the standard distribution, or if it at least would be relaxed to a warning - which the name of the validation already indicates :wink:.. @webron We want to migrate to OAS3. This means

Migrate tools to support both existing OAS2 content and new OAS3 content
Migrate existing OAS2 content

With Swagger Editor 3.x not accepting content that is accepted by Swagger Editor 2.x migration fails in step 1.
Which is why it would be helpful if Swagger Editor 3.x would be more lenient. Making validateTypeKeyShouldBeString a warning instead of an error in the standard 3.x distribution would remove that obstacle.

~Reopening!~. This is going to land in a few parts (this week):

Extending Swagger-Client to handle percent-encoded $refs, while still allowing unescaped values* so that we don't break anyone's documents
Adding validators for unescaped $ref values in Swagger-Editor

Hey @duncanmg, I'm looking at this, expect a reply from me today 😄 . First- wrapActions is an object, you provided an array. Easy mistake, ES2015 shorthand property names tend to look like array items at a glance 😄 
So, wrapActions is used to wrap an action that's already defined by another plugin.  updateSpec is provided by the spec plugin in Swagger-UI, which is why we wrap it in local-storage (but this isn't documented yet, so there's no reason you'd know that). 
If you want to add setSpecName as a new action to specActions, you'll want to do this instead:
js
return {
  statePlugins: {
    spec: {
      wrapActions: {
        updateSpec
      },
      actions: {
        setSpecName
      }
    }
  }
}. Also, once making the changes mentioned above, you should be able to use the specActions prop to call setSpecName instead of passing around setSpecName as a prop. Not having to pass around things is the reason we designed the global system like that 😄 
In order to read the spec name once you set it with setSpecState, you'll want a selector that you can access via specSelectors to match your action. Good example of that in the UI spec plugin.

What's not working for you?. Hey @jaydreyer!
Currently, the validation system is pretty much walled off. If you want to get a custom validator in the existing system today (or modify a current one), the only way is to add a validator file in src/plugins/validation/semantic-validation/validators and create a custom build. See this README for some documentation on how to cook up a validator. The builder should automatically pick up any validator file in that directory.
To do this through the plugin system (always my recommended solution), you'd need to roll your own validator. This isn't too difficult, it's basically a three step process:

Intercept any updates to the resolved spec and trigger your validation: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/blob/master/src/plugins/validation/apis/index.js#L7
Do your validation work. Your spec is the first argument in your updateResolved wrapAction, you can write code that recursively scans your spec for the field you want to validate, not unlike this: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/blob/master/src/plugins/validation/semantic-validators/validators/walker.js#L15
Add any errors you generate to the error state by calling errActions.newSpecErr: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/blob/master/src/plugins/validation/helpers.js#L34. Also, @ponelat's PR this week (https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/pull/1367) added a state-based interface for editor plugins... it may be feasible to create a similar interface for semantic validators to be provided to the existing validation system by end users at runtime.. @jaydreyer, has this helped? Haven't heard back from you 😄 . @jaydreyer, that should be possible! 

As long as you take a spec as an input and provide errors as an output, you should be able to do any sort of validation you'd like to in a plugin.
You won't be able to tie it into the validation system itself (which is a plugin itself), as the one we have is a closed system from a third-party plugin's point of view. You'd, essentially, need to build out your own plumbing. It's not a lot, our validation system is just an abstraction layer and aggregator for all the validators' results.
I mentioned earlier:

(#1367) added a state-based interface for editor plugins... it may be feasible to create a similar interface for semantic validators to be provided to the existing validation system by end users at runtime.

This would allow you to provide validators that work within the existing validation system, taking advantage of the plumbing already present in it. I'm not sure when we'd be able to get around to implementing this, but if you'd like to contribute this functionality, I can write up a detailed specification for the feature..
