Edit 1
Found out that probably the problem is with OpenAPI 2.0. At least, that was where the problem showed up. Also, I was using it wrong.
You can split up your Open API 3.0 API, you just have to use it right and local swagger watcher works fine with it. (swagger-ui-watcher npm module if anyone wants a local swagger client to inspect fast your API and watch for any errors)
How to make a reference to other files?
Easy. There are two ways of referring to a yaml component.
Let's say you want to refer to a animalName parameter component located in your /src/index.yaml file, and you want to refer to it from your /v1/animals/{animal_name} path located in your /src/v1/animals/animalName/index.yaml file. 
First option:
By referring to the file directly and getting everything that is contained in the file
```yaml
/src/index.yaml
paths:
    /v1/animals/:
        $ref: './v1/animals/index.yaml'
components:
    parameters:
        AnimalName:
            $ref: './components/parameters/AnimalName'
/src/components/parameters/AnimalName.yaml
name: animal_name
in: path
required: true
description: Animal's name
schema:
    type: string
/src/v1/animals/animalName/index.yaml
parameters:
    - $ref: '../../../../index.yaml#/components/parameters/AnimalName'
the rest of the path variables ...
**Second option:**
By referring to the file and then getting the specific component from that fileyaml
/src/index.yaml
paths:
    /v1/animals/:
        $ref: './v1/animals/index.yaml#/path'
components:
    parameters:
        AnimalName:
            $ref: './components/parameters/AnimalName#/AnimalName'
/src/components/parameters/AnimalName.yaml
AnimalName:
    name: animal_name
    in: path
    required: true
    description: Animal's name
    schema:
        type: string
/src/v1/animals/animalName/index.yaml
path:
    parameters:
        - $ref: '../../../../index.yaml#/components/parameters/AnimalName'
    # the rest of the path variables ...
```.
psobocinski:
+1 from me as well.
This is actually related to at least a couple other issues:


1896


1709


I wrote a detailed comment about it here, before I found this thread: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/issues/1896#issuecomment-461179149. I am also running into this, except with my use case I'm referencing a specific element in the remote document (i.e. ./resources.yaml#/Pet as opposed to ./pet.yaml).
To reproduce:

Serve the documentation directory (in the below example, docs) using a web server such as http-server
Initialize and run swagger-editor as described in the swagger-editor README (able to reproduce with both npm start and docker run... setup approaches)
Set up your structure inside the docs directory as follows:

docs/test.yaml:
yaml
openapi: 3.0.2
info:
  title: Test
  version: 0.0.0
servers:
  - url: 'http://localhost:8080/docs'
paths:
  '/companies/{company_id}':
    get:
      parameters:
        - $ref: 'components/parameters.yaml#/company_id'
      responses:
        '200':
          $ref: 'components/responses.yaml#/success_company'
docs/components/parameters.yaml:
yaml
company_id:
  name: company_id
  in: path
  required: true
  schema:
    type: integer
    minimum: 1
docs/components/responses.yaml:
yaml
success_company:
  description: OK
  content:
    application/json:
      schema:
        type: object
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
Expected / Actual Behaviour:
Remotely referenced elements load successfully / they fail to load.
Error Details:
I get a JS error when loading test.yaml into Swagger editor (debResolveSubtrees: don't have a system to operate on, aborting.). I've attached the full error from JS console:
swagger-ui-js-error.log
Workaround:
Replacing the remote references with URL references resolves the errors. However this is not an effective workaround for me, so I will be keeping our documentation in one file for now.
Related Issues:
1409 . This is the main thread about the root cause of this issue, I believe.
1709 . Especially note this comment.
As I understand, the servers property replaced the basePath property in OAS3, and should be used to resolve remote (AKA relative) references. 
See swagger docs and OAS3 docs for details / verification.
.

michaeljfazio:
I'm quite confused by this. The redirect_uri is part of the OAuth2 spec (section 3.1.2.  Redirection Endpoint). Whilst it is specified as optional, many Authorisation Servers will not work with authorization_code flow without a redirect_uri specified. For example, we use Keycloak as our Authorization server. The swagger editor will not work with out application because the authorization process fails without the redirect uri.
Am I missing something here?. I think I understand the playing field a bit better now @webron. So, swagger-ui supports the oauth2RedirectUri as part of its API, but swagger-editor does not support it because the core swagger spec does not define a field for it. So, I guess swagger-editor can wait for the spec to catch up with swagger-ui and then bridge the two, or implement a solution to get half way there?
I'm thinking your earlier suggestion of using swagger extensions might be a good middle ground until the spec catches up? Something like x-oauth2RedirectUri: 'http://foobar.com'. When/if the spec catches up (let's face it, it must) then the x- could be dropped?. Thanks @shockey for the clarification. I'll get my guys to check out passing the redirect url as an option to make it all work. In the meantime I have raised an OAI issue https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/issues/1285

So, I think the following should display a nicely indented JSON in the result HTML. 
definitions:
    ERROR-response:            
        type: object
        properties:
            result: 
                type: string

                  ]

{

}
```

"

Thank both of you, guys. :). Oh, yes, thanks. I did not read the specification carefully enough. Sorry for that.
. Thanks, I issued a feature request in order to get this way of specifying a constant value:
https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/issues/1313. Here is my simplified YAML file:
``
swagger: "2.0"
info:
    version: "1.0.0"
    title: My API
host: localhost
paths:
    /auth/account/:
        post:
            summary: "Creates a new user"
            parameters:
              - in: "body"
                name: user data
                required: true
                schema: 
                    type: object
                    properties:
                        email:
                            type: string
                        password:
                            type: string
                        displayed_name:
                            type: string
                    required:
                        - email
                        - password
                        - displayed_name
                    example:
                        email: "johndoe@gmail.com"
                        password: "abc123"
                        displayed_name: "Pocakq"
            responses:
                200:
                    description: Registrationwas` successful
```
The example part is displayed nicely in my locally installed swagger-ui in a visually well separated part. 
On the other hand, the right hand side of the swagger-editor shows the example only as a part of a larger Schema JSON object which I have to open after each changes I made on the left side. So, it is much harder to check the changes in the swagger-editor than it is within swagger-ui. 
Another difference is that the markdown formatting is displayed in the swagger-ui less precisely. See the was part in the last line of the sample YAML. It is rendered nicely with different colour, backround-colour and font in swagger-editor while swagger-ui renders it without any highlighting. . 

. Oh, thanks, I just followed the "Setup with http-server module from GitHub" section of the installation manual from the https://swagger.io/docs/swagger-tools/ page where the old v2.10.4 version number is explicitly mentioned. :)
After upgrading, now the swagger-editor shows exactly the same result as the swagger-ui which is much better, it is less frequently needed to save the yaml file. However, it is still needed every time I want to put it into the local working directory (for committing it or just compare it to the original version). So, the hot key (or manual in worse case) based export still would be a nice feature. 
Actually, I could imagine a plugin system where one could install/write their own *.js functions in a separate file for some operations. Like this:
swaggerEngine.registerMenuItem('File/Export as YAML', 'Ctrl+E', function {
    var yamlContext = swaggerEngine.getYaml();
    jQuery.post('http://my.favourite.service/for/yaml/processing', yamlContext);
});
This would add an Export as YAML menu item to the File menu of the swagger editor which could be invoked with the Ctrl+E hotkey as well. The implementation is the user's decision, now he used jQuery. .

Okeanos:
Okay, maybe I phrased this slightly wrong initially / from a wrong perspective. The Swagger Editor fetches at least three different resources from generator.swagger.io on load even when supplied with a local API file. These are servers. clients, and swagger.json. These may or may not be necessary for the editor to work as such. 
My problem stems from the fact that any user which uses such an intranet hosted editor instance who (for whatever reason, e.g. a local proxy) also has internet access may unknowingly or inadvertently submit API file names and/or contents to swagger.io by using the generator features. Using the standard Docker image I don't see a way to easily disable or reconfigure these extended features. Whether or not the people running and maintaining swagger.io actually do anything with that information is irrelevant I think.
Given that additional Docker images for the validator and the codegen/generator features exist I thought that the Editor could be provisioned similarly to the UI..

dsandor:
@bmschwa Hi Brian, I just came across this issue today and found a solution.  It seems much of the examples I see ask you to specify the parameters in such a way that does not pass validation.  Here is a working example that got me past this issue.
FWIW, I really wish the validation failures provided links to working examples. This would mitigate a lot of frustration because there is so much incorrect or no longer valid examples online.
```
/my/path/{id}:
  get:
    parameters:
    -name: id
      in: path
      required: true
      type: string
. . .
```
For me the change was to specify type: string instead of the long form where I was specifying the schema for the type.  I think that is what threw off validation for me.
The documentation here: https://swagger.io/docs/specification/describing-parameters/ tells us to describe the path parameters with schema which does not work in the editor.  You must (as of today) specify the type on a single line in short form e.g. type: integer or type: string`..

yaml

  title: Example API
  description: Service API.

  /login/local:

            schema:

                - password
              properties:
                emailOrNickname:
                  type: string
                password:
                  type: string

          description: Login successful

                  customer:
                    $ref: "#/components/schemas/Admin"

ASchmidt1:
Thank you webron for your comment. 
As I had stated under "Context" I am already aware of the available, temporary work-arounds (such as changing the server configuration to be lenient). 
The motiviation of documenting bugs is to eventually make some of the countless work-arounds obsolete which server administrators have to maintain (and remember) at any given time as the only interim way to deal with bugs in the myriads of technologies they are expected to support.. I suppose we just disagree on the definition or semantics of "solution":
Whenever you have to "work around" the fact that the underlying problem persists, by IGNORING THE EFFECTS of the problem - then obviously you have not solved the problem of the imprecise Accept header, you literally have implemented a "work-around".
(If our system intentionally enforces strict with Accept... headers we receive from various external sources besides "swagger.io", then being forced to "open up" our system to imperfect/non-compliant/vague outside requests is something we might grudgingly accept temporarily - but only until the original technical shortcoming is addressed.)
. We fully agree - there would be NO problem if */* was used. THAT would be a solution.
It would mean that the server is free to serve its default content-type. THAT is perfectly reasonable - the assumption being that the client's operator knows that they are doing and are willing to cope with whatever we'll deliver.
That is not at all the same than the client explicitly stating that it can only accept the wrong content type for the format requested. To which our server will respond that it has nothing to match that literal request. Again, our system assumes that the client's operator is competent and it is better for them to clarify their ambiguity.. http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html
"Accept headers can be used to indicate that the request is specifically limited to a small set of desired types" ... "If an Accept header field is present, and if the server cannot send a response which is acceptable according to the combined Accept field value, then the server SHOULD send a 406 (not acceptable) response. "
and I know you do appreciate the unique semantic meaning that "SHOULD" has in the context of RFCs.
Therefore, our server fully complies with RFC2616 by responding with a "406" response, because it sending a content-type "application/json" with YAML formatted response would violate other RFCs that explicitly define the "application/json" content-type as being reserved for JSON formatted responses.
It is my believe that the Swagger editor should ENABLE the remote server to implement the application RFCs literally (while I realize that a reasonable work-around is available in the meantime.). I very much do appreciate this now having been recognized as a bug, and a solution being proposed.
Allow me to comment that the media type chosen is NOT registered – nor am I aware that such a registration has even been submitted. 
Contrary what’s being implied IANA will NOT “get around to” arbitrarily assign a media type. It is up to the group managing the YAML specifications to decide upon - and then apply for - a media type to be assigned. I remember them making the argument that while “JSON” was intended to be primarily “machine readable” (thus the application/json type), one motivation for “YAML” was for it to be a easily human readable and editable document (thus the text/yaml type being more applicable).
I therefore question how factual/informed the statement “from what i can tell, application/yaml is likely to be the canonical media type for YAML going forward (once the IANA actually gets around to it...)” is. Can the author of that statement support it by citing the pending registration application, or at minimum the YAML specs, that points to “application/yaml” as the soon-to-come new type?
I respectfully question the wisdom of Swagger ignoring the specs and standardization processes, in favor of unilaterally/casually implementing a different, unregistered media type?

protegesolutions:
Helpful, thanks.. This creates problems with generated code. Partial escaped codes are embedded in types. Please reverse this change.. @shockey @hkosova I came across this today as well. Def files that were fine from months ago are now breaking in Editor. It would be really nice if these back-end BREAKING changes were highlighted to us simple users of Editor (please!). @shockey @hkosova Suggested fix is that supposedly invalid JSON is simply escaped as it probably was being previously. No too difficult, really, and saves all this back-and-forth.. @shockey @hkosova Also, if you make the recommended escaping change to the $ref values (in my case [ and ] to %5B and %5D respectively), you end up with broken client-side - and presumably, server-side - generated code:
    ApiCollection5BString5D AttachmentTags (); instead of ApiCollectionString AttachmentTags ();

    ApiCollection5BCustomFieldCategoryRead5D OpportunityCustomFieldCategories (); instead of ApiCollectionCustomFieldCategoryRead OpportunityCustomFieldCategories ();

This is because the generator removes the % but not the rest of the escape code: %5B -> 5B, %5D -> 5D, etc.
So, essentially, it's now impossible to use Swagger Editor to generate - at least - C# client-side code and probably most of the rest of the code types.
Excellent, well-done!

axnsan12:
Hmh, yes, it seems this details has eluded me 😄 
Well, I guess I will have to adapt my regexes then. 
I don't think supporting more complicated regex flavors would be a good idea from a code geneartion perspective (lowest common denominator and all that), so this can be closed.. By the way, for what it's worth, the original regex is still a valid javascript regex, just with unexpected semantics:
```js


re = /^[-a-zA-Z0-9_]+\Z/
/^[-a-zA-Z0-9_]+\Z/
"this-is-a-slug".match(re)
null
"this-is-a-slugZ".match(re)
Array [ "this-is-a-slugZ" ]
```


i.e. the \Z is just interpreted as a redundantly escaped Z, and it actually works just like that in swagger-ui.
So perhaps this should still not trigger an error in swagger-editor, though it should probably be a warning like "javascript regex does not support \Z as end of input anchor; will be treated as plain Z".. \Z in more advanced regex flavors has the meaning of "end-of-input anchor" (as opposed to $ which is end of line in multi-line mode) - https://www.regular-expressions.info/anchors.html
JavaScript regexes do not support this usage, so my guess would be that they want to prevent confusion caused by \Z suddenly matching a literal Z instead of end of input, since there is usually no reason you would have an escaped Z when you really mean Z. Which I guess would be right, it did catch my error which was exactly that (I was directly printing a python regex into a swagger spec).
. So in short \Z is techincally a valid regex, but probably invalid from the point of view of what the user intended, which is probably the reasoning for that error. .

handrews:
@jennaprice you need to put the $ref inside of an allOf.  This limitation will be removed in JSON Schema draft-08, although it's not clear when or how OpenAPI will support newer drafts of JOSN Schema.
here's what your first two examples would look like:
YAML
/endpoint
  post:
   requestBody: 
          description: Create a Person
          required: true
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                allOf:
                  - $ref: '#/components/schemas/person'
                required:
                  - firstName
                  - lastName
                properties:
                  firstName:
                    type: string
                  lastName:
                    type: string
YAML
/endpoint
  post:
   requestBody: 
          description: Create a Person
          required: true
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                allOf:
                  - $ref: '#/components/schemas/person'
                required:
                  - firstName
                  - lastName
.

2018-07-25 11:22 GMT+02:00 Helen Kosova notifications@github.com:

Your spec is not valid - OpenAPI 2.0 does not support $ref in response
headers. You need to replace the $ref with an inline header definition.
$ref'erencing response headers is supported in OpenAPI 3.0 though, check
out the example here: OAI/OpenAPI-Specification#1586 (comment)
https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/issues/1586#issuecomment-391128098.
Note that reusable headers are stored in #/components/headers, not
/components/schemas.

Download the latest version ("Source code (.zip)") from the Releases page:
https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/releases
Unzip.
Open the index.html file in your browser.
In this case you only need the index.html file + files in the dist folder, so you can delete other files (src, test, etc.).

Or if you want to run the editor on localhost using node: 


cd into the repository root folder, then run: 


npm install


npm start


Open http://localhost:3001 in your browser.

linelson:
@shockey thanks for getting this merged in!. The reason for the change was that the casing React was breaking webpack-dev-server for a React app created using create-react-app https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app when the standalone preset was imported from https://www.npmjs.com/package/swagger-editor-dist. 
Here's the error:
Failed to compile.
./node_modules/swagger-editor-dist/swagger-editor-standalone-preset.js
Module not found: `C:\Users\linels\repos\react-app\src\node_modules\React\index.js` does not match the corresponding path on disk `react`.
CaseSensitivePathsPlugin, which is used by create-react-app, appears to be the culprit.
Ejecting create-react-app and removing dependencies on CaseSensitivePathsPlugin allows webpack-dev-server to run without problems with either casing.
When the standalone preset bundle is created with casing react: 'react' webpack-dev-server works as expected without needing to eject and remove dependencies on CaseSensitivePathsPlugin. . No objections here to its removal.. Let me know if you'd like me to send a PR for this.. I'll send a PR sometime this week.. @shockey https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/pull/1903.

In addition, the issue seems to show up only with relative URIs, but it works fine with absolute URIs in the $ref.. not sure i got what you meant exactly by this issue; just to comment that both examples you wrote above, express different presence requirments for phone and email properties.
1st example requires that either phone or email or both properties are present in the request.
2nd example requires that either phone or email but not both properties are present in the request.. > why in this case both can't be present in the request? If the property is not in the required it doesn't mean it can't be presented in the request
because that's how oneOf works... if you have both properties present in the request, both branches in the oneOf will be "true", and therefore, the oneOf check will fail, since oneOf requires that only one of the branches is true.
. Looks like normal CORS behaviour. Before sending POST request to a different server ("different" means a server other than the server in the URL of the page you're accessing), the browser sends OPTIONS and expects to receive Access-Control-Allow-Methods header in the response. If it doesn't, CORS is not allowed, and the real request (POST) is not even sent.. What I meant is that what you're seeing is the normal behaviour of the browser, enforcing the CORS standard. There is nothing the Swagger tools can do about it: if you test your API from, say, swaggerhub.com, or editor.swagger.io, and your test API server is in a different host, then your browser will trigger CORS enforcement..
